2.8 Responsibility and agency in Confucian ethics

In many respects, the ethics associated with the canonical figures of
Confucius, Mencius, and Xunzi is about the way people should respond
to one another, and in this sense it is a paradigmatic ethic of
responsibility. Confucian ethics exemplifies, along with most other
ethics, the idea that we must be responsive to, held responsible for,
that which makes us morally valuable.  Confucian virtues
of ren, yi, li, and filiality are conceived
to make their possessor trustworthy and reliable responders to the
needs, welfare, and dignity of others. The centrality that Confucian
ethics accords to relationship in what is valuable in human life
results in some distinctive features of its conception of
responsibility. A supreme degree of responsiveness to the needs and
suffering of people is required of exemplary officials. In Mencius
4B29, Yu, legendary for working tirelessly to control the flooding of
the great rivers of China and who later became King, is described as
regarded those drowning as if he had drowned them himself. Ji, who
bore his official responsibilities in a time of famine, regarded those
starving as if he had starved them himself.  Xunzi says
that Tian gave birth to the people not for the sake of their
lords, but established the lords for the sake of the people (chapter
27). 

The authority of rulers rests on their being given the responsibility
for bringing about the conditions under which their people can live
fulfilling lives and develop their virtue. Recall Mencius’ declaration
to King Xuan that if the people do not have a constant means of
livelihood, they will not have the constant minds to set themselves on
developing their virtue, and fall into crime (1A7). If a king allows
such circumstances to afflict his people, if his people commit crimes
to feed themselves and their families, and if the king punishes them,
he will have entrapped them. Mencius’ declaration, then, amounts to
distributing a great share of the responsibility for the people’s
crimes to their king.

Mencius goes on to propose concrete policies to the king to avoid
entrapping the people: not overtaxing them to fund aggressive wars
against neighboring states, prohibiting close-mesh fishing nets so as
not to catch young fish and turtles, limiting the harvesting of trees
to certain seasons, and planting mulberry trees so that the people
will have silk clothing to wear (1A3, 1A7). Such policies make for
sufficiently fertile soil from which his people’s duan might
grow. Mencius might here be construed as invoking what has been called
“circumstantial luck” by Thomas Nagel in his classic “Moral Luck”
essay (1976). While we do have control over some of our circumstances,
we have none or very little control over other circumstances that
greatly affect what can we make of ourselves. This is the source of
Nagel’s intuition that an arbitrariness of evaluation infects our
judgments of what we tend to hold people to answer for.  Some of
us have very unfavorable circumstances in which we choose, yet others
with more favorable circumstances get more credit for their choices.
Interestingly, the only exception Mengzi makes to the rule that those
without a constant means will be unable to have a constant mind is the
class of shi 士, the gentry-scholar class of which
Mengzi himself was a member. In an era of great political turbulence
and disintegrating social order, members of this class were dislodged
from their comfortable niches in the lower aristocracy, but their
knowledge of traditions made them valuable to competing warlord-kings
who wished to replicate the glory of the old kings. This distinct set
of circumstances for the shi made genteel poverty and itinerancy more
favorable, or at least less adverse, circumstances for maintaining a
constant mind than others lower in the social order.

People normally have responsibility to refrain from crime, which
involves their responsibility to respond to the needs of their
potential victims, but that responsibility can be mitigated by the
lack of control they have to avoid severe suffering if they refrain
from crime. Their responsibility is mitigated by the way desperation
focuses the mind on self and those for whom one cares the most. When
governments fail to realize the material conditions under which their
people could devote adequate attention to the development of their
virtue, they share a great deal of the responsibility for the
wrongdoing and harm that results.

Though Xunzi has a very different theory of what happens in the
cultivation of virtue, he too believes that helping individuals to
become competent moral agents is a collective task.
He recounts a story that occurred when Confucius was Minister of
Justice. A father and son had become embroiled in a legal
dispute. Kongzi detained them both but ultimately releases both. When
questioned as to why he let the son go when he should have been
punished for being unfilial, Kongzi questions the permissibility
of killing subordinates when their superiors are at fault: to
fail to teach the people and then judge their crimes is to kill the
innocent; to fail to teach the people and yet hold them responsible
for achieving meritorious works is being cruel; it is only when one
stops these practices that it is permissible to apply
punishments (chapter 28, see translation by Hutton 2014: 319).
However, if the material conditions sufficient for the focusing
of one’s attention on moral virtue are present, and if others capable
of pointing the way toward learning are available to be followed, then
it is up to the individual to put in the effort (see Mencius 6A9 and
Jiang 2002). 

Lack of control over the conditions under which one becomes a
responsible moral agent, as discussed above, can result in mitigation
of personal responsibility. However, it is also possible to become
responsible for what is not under one’s control. This can happen
because others who commit a moral wrong stand in special relationship
to oneself. In addition, such others can enter so deeply into
one’s identity that one cannot repudiate what they do without
disowning part of the self. In the text Kongzi Jiayu
(孔子家語 The School Sayings of
Confucius, 37.4 – see Other Internet Resources), a story is told
of the time Kongzi refrains from denouncing the unseemly conduct of an
old friend and does not distance himself from it or his friend. In
explaining this, Kongzi says that family members never lose that which
makes them family and old friends never lose that which makes them old
friends. Deep and lasting friendship can make us partly responsible
for the misconduct of our friends (see Ing 2017 for an illuminating
discussion of this passage).

Such consequences for the allotment of responsibility stem from the
moral centrality given to relationship in Confucian ethics, but are
not peculiar to Confucian ethics. Margaret Urban Walker (1993) has
observed that moral agents who accept responsibility for circumstances
beyond their control and who therefore “recognize their vulnerability
to fortune are primed for dependability of humanly invaluable sorts”
and “won’t fail us even under the blows of bad fortune or odd turns of
fate which might otherwise prompt denial or opportunism” (1993,
25–26).

Agency, then, can be distributed among a larger group of people and is
not limited to the agent who directly chooses the action in question;
it is distributed among those who can some significant degree of
control over the conditions under which the direct agent chooses.
Others can share responsibility through having a relevant relationship
to the direct agent. A significant degree of responsibility is
retained by the direct agent, however, especially if the conditions
(such as a constant means of livelihood and the presence of reliable
teachers and models) favorable to the development of agency are
present. Then responsibility is conceived to rest on the individual to
exercise their heart-mind. In Mencius’ case, the individual needs to
exercise the heart-mind’s capacity to think about the importance of
developing the moral duan within; in Xunzi’s case,
the individual needs to reflect on what qualities of character and
what kinds of cooperative relationships with others would provide
the greatest, and most stable satisfaction of desire. In each case,
there is an internal normative hierarchywithin the person that should
be established, with the heart-mind as the leader or commander of the
rest of the person. The heart-mind directs how the person should
cultivate the self and conduct itself in relation to others. This
hierarchy corresponds to the meritocratic order that Confucians
believe should obtain in state and society: the most virtuous and
most able (those who have developed their heart-minds the most) should
have the most authority to govern. We shall see how
the Zhuangzi (section 4.2) in particular poses a
striking critique of both forms of hierarchy.
